Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Story:
The family group chat buzzes with plans for the upcoming holiday. My daughter sends a message: “Dad, can you help organize the games this year? The kids are so excited to see you!” I smile, picturing my grandkids’ faces, but my phone vibrates again—this time, it’s a Slack notification from work. The QA team has flagged a critical bug, and users are already complaining about app crashes. My manager’s message is clear: “We need a fix before the weekend, can you jump on a call?”

I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family expects me to be present, to keep our traditions alive, to be the grandfather who listens and laughs and makes memories. But my team is counting on me too; I’m the only one who understands this part of the codebase. I stare at the two screens, heart tugged in opposite directions, wondering how I can possibly be in both places at once.
